contents.description:
To make a webpage responsive, I use CSS media queries, flexible layouts like Flexbox and Grid, responsive units, and fluid images. I follow a mobile-first approach, include the viewport meta tag, and often use frameworks like Bootstrap or Tailwind. This ensures the layout adapts smoothly across different devices.


Using Responsive Units:

Avoid fixed px and use:

  • % (percentage)
  • vw / vh (viewport width/height)
  • rem / em (scalable font sizes)
  • minmax() in CSS Grid

Responsive Images

  • Use max-width: 100% so images shrink with screen size
  • Use srcset for different resolutions
  • Use picture tag for device-specific images
img {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

Mobile-First Design

Start designing for small screens, then scale up using media queries.

/* Base (mobile) */
button { width: 100%; }

/* Tablet/Desktop */
@media (min-width: 768px) {
  button { width: auto; }
}

Viewport Meta Tag (mandatory for mobile)

Without this, your page won’t scale properly on mobile.

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
contents.text: How do you make a webpage responsive?

contents.description:
Media queries are CSS techniques that apply styles conditionally based on the device characteristics like screen width, height, orientation, or resolution, enabling responsive web design.


/* Mobile devices */
@media (max-width: 480px) { ... }

/* Tablets */
@media (max-width: 768px) { ... }

/* Small laptops */
@media (max-width: 1024px) { ... }

/* Large desktops */
@media (min-width: 1200px) { ... }


// Orientation
@media (orientation: landscape) { ... }

// High DPI / Retina Screens
@media (min-resolution: 2dppx) { ... }

// Print Styles
@media print {
  body { color: black; }
}

// Mobile only
@media (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 768px) { ... }

max-width applies CSS when the screen width is less than or equal to the given value.

min-width applies CSS when the screen width is greater than or equal to the given value.

The CSS Box Model defines how every element is structured using content, padding, border, and margin. It determines how total space is calculated for any element on the page.

A CSS selector is a pattern that tells the browser which HTML elements to apply styles to.

Selectors can target elements by tag, class, id, attributes, pseudo-classes, and their relationships in the DOM.

Specificity is the rule that decides which CSS style applies when multiple rules target the same element, based on a points hierarchy of selectors.


Specificity Hierarchy (Highest → Lowest):

  1. Inline styles → style="..." → 1000 points
  2. ID selectors → #id → 100 points
  3. Class, pseudo-class, attribute selectors → .class, [type="text"], :hover → 10 points
  4. Element & pseudo-element selectors → div, p, ::before → 1 point
  5. Universal selector *, combinators (>, +, ~) → 0 points

Centering a div can be done in multiple ways. The modern approach is using Flexbox with justify-content: center and align-items: center. Another clean method is CSS Grid using place-items: center. For horizontal-only centering, we use margin: 0 auto. For older layouts, we can center using position: absolute with transform.
contents.text: How do you center a div (horizontally & vertically)?

contents.description: display: none removes the element from the document flow completely, so it doesn’t take any space. visibility: hidden hides the element but keeps its space reserved. Layout shifts with display: none, while with visibility: hidden, the layout stays the same.

relative keeps the element in the normal flow but allows slight movement. absolute removes the element from the flow and positions it relative to the nearest positioned ancestor. fixed also removes the element from flow, but it stays fixed in the viewport even on scroll.

Flexbox is a one-dimensional CSS layout system that helps align items and distribute space efficiently along a row or column. It makes tasks like centering, spacing, and responsive design much easier using properties like flex-direction, justify-content, and align-items.

CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system in CSS that lets you create responsive layouts using rows and columns. It allows precise control over spacing, alignment, and placement of elements, making it ideal for complex page structures and grid-based designs.

Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout system used for arranging items in a row or column, perfect for smaller components. CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system that handles both rows and columns, making it ideal for complex page layouts.


Flexbox is content-driven, while Grid is layout-driven.

A pseudo-class is a keyword added to a selector that defines a special state of an element. It allows you to style elements based on user interaction, position, or other conditions, without adding extra classes or IDs in HTML.

selector:pseudo-class {
  /* styles */
}

Pseudo-class Description Example
:hoverWhen the user hovers over an elementbutton:hover { background: blue; }
:activeWhen the element is being clickeda:active { color: red; }
:focusWhen an input or button is focusedinput:focus { border-color: green; }
:first-childSelects the first child of its parentli:first-child { font-weight: bold; }
:last-childSelects the last child of its parentli:last-child { font-style: italic; }
:nth-child(n)Selects the nth childli:nth-child(2) { color: red; }
:not()Selects elements that do not match a selectorp:not(.special) { color: gray; }

  • Pseudo-classes (:hover, :first-child) → style the whole element based on state or position.
  • Pseudo-elements (::before, ::after) → style part of the element or insert content.

A pseudo-element allows you to style specific parts of an element’s content or insert content without adding extra HTML elements. It targets a portion of the element, unlike pseudo-classes which target the whole element based on state.

selector::pseudo-element {
  /* styles */
}

Pseudo-element Description Example
::beforeInserts content before the element’s contentp::before { content: "Note: "; font-weight: bold; }
::afterInserts content after the element’s contentp::after { content: " ✔"; color: green; }
::first-letterStyles the first letter of an elementp::first-letter { font-size: 2rem; color: red; }
::first-lineStyles the first line of an elementp::first-line { font-weight: bold; }
::markerStyles the list item marker (bullet or number)li::marker { color: red; font-size: 1.2rem; }

  • Pseudo-classes (:hover, :first-child) → style the whole element based on state or position.
  • Pseudo-elements (::before, ::after) → style part of the element or insert content.

The z-index property in CSS controls the stacking order of elements along the z-axis (depth). Elements with a higher z-index appear on top of elements with a lower z-index.


Only works on elements that have a position value of relative, absolute, fixed, or sticky.

The calc() function in CSS allows you to perform mathematical calculations to determine property values.

You can combine different units (%, px, em, rem, etc.) in one expression.


selector {
  property: calc(expression);
}


h1 {
  font-size: calc(16px + 1vw); /* base 16px + 1% of viewport width */
}
Responsive design is an approach in web development where a website adapts its layout and content to look good on all devices and screen sizes—desktops, tablets, and mobile phones.

em → relative to parent, can compound.

rem → relative to root, consistent across page.

% → relative to parent container.

vh / vw → relative to viewport, great for full-screen layouts.

The overflow property in CSS controls what happens when content inside an element exceeds its defined width or height.


selector {
  overflow: visible | hidden | scroll | auto;
}

Value Description
visible (default)Content overflows the box and is fully visible outside the container.
hiddenContent that exceeds the box is clipped and not visible.
scrollAlways shows scrollbars, even if content fits inside.
autoAdds scrollbars only when needed (content overflows).

The object-fit property specifies how an image or video should be resized to fit its container while maintaining its aspect ratio (or not).

It is commonly used with <img> or <video> elements.


img {
  object-fit: fill | contain | cover | none | scale-down;
}

The box-sizing property in CSS defines how the total width and height of an element are calculated.


content-box (Default)

  • Width & height include only the content.
  • Padding and border are added outside, increasing the total size.

div {
  width: 200px;
  padding: 20px;
  border: 10px solid black;
  box-sizing: content-box; /* default */
}

Total width = content width + padding + border = 200 + (20*2) + (10*2) = 260px


border-box:

  • Width & height include content + padding + border.
  • Makes layout sizing easier and avoids overflow issues.

div {
  width: 200px;
  padding: 20px;
  border: 10px solid black;
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

Total width = 200px (includes content, padding, and border)

SCSS (Sassy CSS) is used for styling and provides extra superpowers. It allows us to use features like variables ($primary-color), nesting, mixins, functions, partials and imports, and inheritance (@extend).

SCSS variables are placeholders used to store reusable values such as colors, font sizes, spacing, breakpoints, or any value you want to use multiple times in your styles.


$primary-color: #3498db;
$font-large: 18px;

button {
  background-color: $primary-color;
  font-size: $font-large;
}
Nesting in SCSS allows you to write selectors inside other selectors, reducing repetition and making your styles more structured and readable.

A mixin in SCSS is a reusable CSS code block that we can include anywhere using @include. It helps reduce repetition and keeps your code clean.


@mixin center-flex {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
}
.box {
  width: 100px;
  height: 100px;
  @include center-flex;
}

Mixins with Parameters:

@mixin font-size-weight($size, $weight) {
  font-size: $size;
  font-weight: $weight;
}

.title {
  @include font-size-weight(24px, 600);
}

SCSS functions allow you to perform calculations or logic and return a value.

They make your CSS more dynamic, powerful, and maintainable.


@function theme-color($shade) {
  @if $shade == 'primary' {
    @return #3498db;
  } @else if $shade == 'success' {
    @return #2ecc71;
  } @else {
    @return #333;
  }
}

.button {
  color: theme-color('success');
}

@extend in SCSS is a feature that allows one selector to inherit the styles of another selector.


.message {
  padding: 10px;
  border-radius: 5px;
}

.success {
  @extend .message;
  background: green;
}

.warning {
  @extend .message;
  background: orange;
}

A partial is an SCSS file whose name starts with an underscore (_) and is meant to be imported into other SCSS files.


// _variables.scss
$primary-color: #3498db;
$font-size-base: 16px;

// _mixins.scss
@mixin flex-center {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
}


@use 'variables';
@use 'mixins';

button {
  background: variables.$primary-color;
  @include mixins.flex-center;
}

@import is the old way and is not recommended by the Sass team. When we use @import, it merges everything into a single global scope, which can lead to name conflicts, slow compilation, and duplicate imports.


@use is the recommended approach. It does not pollute the global scope, and it allows us to access variables, mixins, and functions using a namespace.


@forward is used when creating a central SCSS file that re-exports other partials.
SCSS helps improve performance by reducing CSS size through the use of variables, mixins, functions, nesting, and partials. It also removes duplicate styles using @extend.
SASS uses indentation-based syntax without braces or semicolons, while SCSS uses CSS-like syntax with braces and semicolons.

A media query is used to apply CSS depending on device characteristics—mainly screen size—to make websites responsive and user-friendly across all devices.


@media (min-width: 250px) {
  .your-class {
    /* styles here */
  }
}

@media (min-width: 450px) and (max-width: 1200px) {
  .your-class {
    /* styles here */
  }
}

@media (max-width: 1800px) {
  .your-class {
    /* styles here */
  }
}
